thread.title: When people escape domestic violence, what happens to their pets
thread.title_full: When people escape domestic violence, what happens to their pets

title: When people escape domestic violence, what happens to their pets
text:
Map: Mount Gambier 5290 
There is a need to establish avenues to remove animals from situations of domestic violence, the director of a south-east domestic violence service says. 
Domestic violence shelters in Australia are often not set-up to take in animals, and animal shelters in many regional areas are not equipped to handle short-term crisis accommodation. 
And for many animals caught up in situations where there is domestic violence, the animal can become a victim as well. 
"It is a common story that we hear, that it is one of the tactics that a male perpetrator does use against a woman," manager of the Limestone Coast Domestic Violence Service, Susie Smith said. 
According to Ms Smith, in the women's shelter she manages, is not uncommon to hear women — the overwhelming victims of domestic violence — say that they stayed in a situation to protect their pets. 
"Sometimes [victims] choose not to leave that pet because some the tactics of male perpetrators is to actually hurt pets, because they know that actually really hurts the victim as well," she said. 
"They know that they are often leaving that pet in a very unsafe situation. 
"If they can't find a relative or a friend to look after the pet, then they are weighing up between their own safety and the safety of their pet, which is a really difficult thing." RSPCA steps in to help 
While there is currently no system set up to remove animals for domestic violence situations in regional South Australia, Peter Ferguson from the RSPCA said the organisation would endeavour to assist anyone in that situation. 
"We certainly wouldn't turn anybody away," he said. 
"The best place to start is probably the support agency that the individual is talking to; we have relationships and we are building more of those relationships." 
The RSPCA in South Australia is looking to expand the small-scale program of crisis pet accommodation it has — that cares for about 150 pets — after becoming aware of the need. 
They currently run a program called Safe Kennels, which has been funded with the assistance of government grants and private donors, and allows pets to stay for up to 100 days. A woman's first-hand account of husband's attempt to kill her 
"What that involves is some physical kennels at our shelters, as well as ... working on relationships with domestic violence and mental health and homelessness support agencies," Mr Ferguson said. 
"What we have at the moment is quite small-scale — we care for the pets of around 150 families," he said. 
He said the organisation was also trying to establish a foster care program for short and indefinite accommodation of pets. 
"We are looking at potentially setting up a program where people who have been through a difficult situation in their life can actually care for the animal of someone who is going through a similar situation," Mr Ferguson said. 
"Someone who has escaped a domestic violence situation, for example, might take in the dog of a woman or a family who are looking to escape that same situation." 
The genesis of establishing a formal program came after the RSPCA began noticing a need in the community for the service. 
"We had been running this program on an ad hoc basis for a number of years," Mr Ferguson said. 
"We have seen the need in the community is quite large for this service." Connecting animal abuse and domestic violence 
According to Mr Ferguson, studies from Australia and across the world have linked animal abuse and domestic violence. 
"We have people who are working very closely with domestic violence support agencies, and looking into some of the research that's been done," Mr Ferguson said. 
"There is substantial evidence that exists worldwide — not just here in South Australia — documenting the connection between animal abuse and domestic violence." 
He said the research has found abuse of pets often occurred before and during human abuse in a domestic violence situation. 
"Sadly, a major reason for the abuse of pets by perpetrators is to control women and children," Mr Ferguson said. 
"It is a really horrible situation that these people find themselves in. They have a pet and the pet is being used in a manipulative way, and they need to get themselves and their pet out." 
Would having domestic violence shelters for animals make a difference? 
"It would make a huge difference," Ms Smith said. 
"It would provide so much more support for women leaving, it wouldn't provide a barrier for her seeking safety, and it would just make things a whole lot easier."
